div.p: Your letter has been delivered to me.
I will be brief; for I am miserably tormented by my domestic enemy, a very severe headache, which afflicts me almost every month.

There is no need for you to be concerned about Bernardinus; yesterday he departed for Basel; if he is not received there, he might perhaps travel to his associates in Poland; for I do not know where else he could go.
You will understand the whole matter from what I have enclosed; but please return them.
He left before the set time for departure, being aware of his own wrongdoing; he feared the criticism of his book.
The two dialogues on the Trinity that he wrote are most pestilent and should be utterly trampled underfoot.
Do not worry about the Rhaetian wine; as much as I need it for my dear guests, Hans WÃ¤gman will provide for me in due time.

Stoker has returned from Lyon and reported to me that everything in France is now peaceful; regarding the true religion, things are going very well and there is great hope; the king is also very hopeful.
Therefore, the Swiss legion has been dismissed; those who remain are all returning. The authorities are selling the church properties, etc.

Greet the consuls, Gallicius, Pontisella, and the other brothers, especially my most esteemed Martinengo; you can share the main action with Bernardinus with him; I also recently informed him of some of it. December 3, 1563.
To the most excellent man, Mr. Johannes Fabricius, minister of the church in Chur, my dearest brother.
